Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Geological Hazards, Climate Change, and Human/Ecosystems Resilience in the Islands of the Four Mountains, Alaska.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Assessing the degree to which geological hazards in the Aleutian archipelago disrupted prehistoric human and ecological systems has important lessons for current inhabitants of the northern Pacific Rim. The Islands of Four Mountains region embodies environmental instabilities that, in the last 10,000 years, include changing subarctic climate, volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, tsunamis, and sea level fluctuations. Compared to adjacent regions to the east and west, strong ocean currents and smaller island size magnify ecologically-driven resource extremes, perhaps creating a physical bottleneck and the cultural boundary that persisted into the early 20th century. These islands provide an excellent opportunity to assess the development of prehistoric human adaptations to geological hazards and environmental change. That such research has not already occurred is understandable. The same volcanic activity, precipitous coastlines, high winds, and strong riptides that may have posed profound risks to prehistoric individuals hinder modern research expeditions. The Four Mountain prehistoric sites are little studied but are highly significant in light of new geologic data indicating volcanic activity during human migration and societal development in the Aleutian archipelago. A team of professional and student archaeologists, geologists, ecologists, and zoologists will conduct a comprehensive, interdisciplinary three-year investigation in the Islands of the Four Mountains. Extensive new radiocarbon, geological, paleoenvironmental, and cultural data expected from these sites will yield novel insights into the record of geological hazards, human coping mechanisms, changing subsistence, and adaptations during the prehistoric and European contact periods.

The Islands of the Four Mountains are located in an ecologically and economically important region of the world - the north Pacific and Bering Sea. People on two continents rely on fish from its marine ecosystem, and, given the sensitivity of airplanes to volcanic ash and of coastal cities to tsunamis, its geologic hazards potentially affect all nations of the northern Pacific Rim. Comprehensive research on long-term human-environmental interactions in the Bering Sea region, set against a backdrop of accelerated global change, is vital to understanding the dynamics of Aleutian biological and human systems and effectively addressing the social, political, and economic issues that arise from changes in those system dynamics today. The island group lies in a zone of high catastrophic potential in that one of its volcanoes, Mt. Cleveland, has erupted explosively more than 20 times in the last decade (as recently as May 2013) and during the time of prehistoric human habitation. The Aleutian plate boundary is the site of four earthquakes having a magnitude greater than 8 and dozens with magnitudes greater than 7, and these have generated tsunamis historically and prehistorically. Through partnerships with the Alaska Volcano Observatory, the Aleut Corporation, Museum of the Aleutians, and the Keck Geology Consortium this project will bring scientists, Native Americans, students and policy makers together in education and collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aleutian archaeological sites are North Pacific observation networks that provide valuable information about prehistoric peoples and their subarctic world. These islands and the cultural materials they contain provide information on past geological and biological change and human responses to those fluctuations. Our international science team (Canada, Russia, Japan, and U.S.A.) combined archaeology, paleoecology, and volcanic ash studies to answer questions about the Aleutian past.   

            Our research shows that, although resources were limited by the steep landscape and small size of the islands that comprise the Four Mountain Islands, Aleutian maritime hunter-gatherers used nearly all available in-shore and off-shore animals and plants including sea mammals, birds, fish, shellfish, and crowberries. The most abundant animal remains in Four Mountains archaeological deposits include: sea urchins, Pacific cod, Irish lord, whiskered auklet, ancient murrelet, and Steller sea lion. Seasonality studies indicate that hunter-gatherers occupied villages year around. Despite human harvesting, most animal populations remained stable; however, humans sometimes overexploited storm petrels, small birds that nest on the ground in large colonies.

            Timing of changes in human activity depends on accurate dating techniques. In the Aleutians, dating is most accurate when samples are derived from terrestrial materials transported by humans to prehistoric sites. Terrestrial dates in the Aleutians include: plants burned during volcanic eruptions or by human activity, bones of terrestrial feeding birds, or artifacts including baskets and mats constructed of locally grown grasses. Although archaeologists commonly date charcoal or wood, in the Aleutians these originate from driftwood that may have floated in the sea, or been buried, for years or centuries. Also, some Aleutian dates are incorrect because of the so-called marine reservoir effect. North Pacific waters comprise a reservoir of ancient carbon that returns to the surface during ocean upwelling and this upwelling varies across the North Pacific. Marine mammals, fish, shellfish, and many birds derive sustenance from the sea. Subsequently, these animals incorporate this ancient carbon, which makes dated bones and shell appear unusually old. Because trees do not grow in the Four Mountains, and because driftwood is limited, prehistoric people burned crowberry shrubs, probably to heat food. We radiocarbon dated charred crowberries (terrestrials) recovered from excavations and compared these dates with those from fish (marine) bones recovered in the same archaeological levels. The differences in dates provided a correction factor of approximately 500 years, which can be used to correct marine derived dates at other eastern Aleutians prehistoric sites.

            Tephrochronology is the study of the sequence and origin of volcanic eruptions represented by ash falls and their impact on the landscape. Our team tephrochronologist analyzed distinctive volcanic ash deposits across the islands and within Four Mountains prehistoric village sites. Chemically testing and radiocarbon dating ash layers he identified a distinctive, 1050- year-old ash that he named CR-02 ash. Based on thickness distribution of the CR-02 ash, its vent source lies on the north coast of Cleveland volcano, currently one of the most active volcanoes in the Aleutian Islands. Evidence suggests the volcanic eruption that created the CR-02 ash might have forced prehistoric peoples to abandon some villages in the Four Mountain islands for a time.  Colony-nesting birds like petrels fertilize soils with their nitrogen rich guano. Team paleobiologists noted a severe decline in colonial nesting birds (based on minimal nitrogen content in peat deposits) prior to the CR-02 ash fall; after the ash fell, nitrogen levels increased in the peat deposit. The sudden increase in peat deposit nitrogen after the CR-02 ash-fall suggests that bird colonies quickly recovered, and prehistoric humans were not present to hunt them.    

            Team archaeologists worked with a local history teacher as Unalaska high school students sorted archaeological samples recovered from a prehistoric village site. Students were provided with advice on identifying fish, bird, and mammal remains and human artifacts. Community involvement also included showing Unalaska Girl Scouts/Brownies Four Mountains artifacts and discussing prehistoric Aleutian life ways. This project also provided training and/or materials to graduate students at the University of Kansas and University of York, United Kingdom.  Four Mountains researchers worked with other archaeologists, ecologists, marine biologists, and museum staff to develop a travelling exhibit entitled “Underwater Forests of the Aleutians.” The exhibit is on display at the Museum of the Aleutians and will travel throughout the North Pacific to Adak, Nikolski, Akutan, and the Pribilof Islands to engage the public, school children, and Native communities about the relationships among humans, kelp forests, sea urchins, and marine mammals.

            Prehistoric peoples in the Four Mountains lived relatively high above sea level to avoid Pacific tsunamis, were able to move quickly to surrounding islands when volcanic eruptions occurred, and repeatedly returned to their villages when conditions improved. Aleutian peoples were resourceful generalists who made their livings from all aspects of their surroundings. These examples of past ingenuity can inform people who today live in coastal regions of Alaska.
